source.name: City of Edmonton Waste Services
source.notes: Based on City of Edmonton waste services guidelines. Blue bag recycling. Green cart for organics. EPR program since Jan 2025. WasteWise App for item lookup. Eco Stations for hazardous waste.

materials.name: Newspaper
notes: Edmonton uses blue bags for recycling — available at City distribution events and some retailers
As of Jan 2025, EPR program means mixed bagged recycling accepted at depots
commonMistakes: Don't put loose recyclables at curbside — must be in a blue bag

materials.name: Magazines and flyers
notes: Glossy paper and staples accepted
commonMistakes: Don't remove staples

materials.name: Office paper and mail
notes: All clean paper accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels or tissues

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Place in blue bag or beside cart
notes: Large cardboard can be flattened and placed beside your collection area
commonMistakes: Don't include cardboard soaked with grease
Remove all styrofoam and packing materials

materials.name: Boxboard / thin cardboard
notes: Thin cardboard boxes accepted
commonMistakes: Remove plastic liners if possible

materials.name: Milk and juice cartons
notes: Gable-top and aseptic (Tetra Pak) cartons accepted
commonMistakes: Don't flatten — keep 3-dimensional

materials.name: Plastic bottles
notes: Rigid plastic containers accepted
Use WasteWise App for specific item lookup
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid still in them

materials.name: Rigid plastic containers
notes: Rigid plastic containers accepted
commonMistakes: No foam containers
Rinse food residue

materials.name: Milk jugs
notes: HDPE #2 — highly recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't leave milk residue

materials.name: Aluminum beverage cans
notes: Beverage containers can also go to a bottle depot for refund
Alberta has a beverage container deposit system
commonMistakes: Don't crush — keep 3-dimensional for sorting

materials.name: Food cans
notes: All metal food cans accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still in them

materials.name: Aluminum foil
instructions: Ball up into a fist-sized ball
notes: Must be clean
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil with baked-on food

materials.name: Glass bottles
notes: All colours of glass accepted
Beverage containers eligible for deposit refund at bottle depots
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass — wrap and place in garbage
Don't include ceramics or window glass

materials.name: Glass jars
notes: Labels can stay on
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass

materials.name: Aerosol cans
notes: Non-empty aerosols go to an Eco Station
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurized

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place bagged shredded paper in blue bag
notes: Loose shredded paper is too small for sorting
commonMistakes: Don't put loose shredded paper in the blue bag

materials.name: Books
instructions: Damaged books: place in blue bag
notes: Edmonton Public Library accepts donations
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in garbage

materials.name: Pizza box (clean)
instructions: If the pizza box is clean, place in blue bag
Tear off the clean lid for recycling; compost the greasy bottom
notes: Clean portions are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include greasy portions — those go in the green cart

materials.name: Food waste (all types)
instructions: Place all food scraps in the green cart
Includes meat, bones, dairy, cooked food, raw food
Line cart with newspaper or certified compostable bag
notes: Edmonton green cart accepts all food waste including meat and dairy
Green cart collected weekly
commonMistakes: Don't put food in the garbage if you have green cart service
Don't use regular plastic bags

materials.name: Fruit and fruit scraps
notes: All fruit and fruit scraps accepted
commonMistakes: Remove fruit stickers

materials.name: Vegetables and vegetable scraps
notes: All vegetables accepted
commonMistakes: Remove twist ties and elastic bands

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Place in green cart — Edmonton accepts ALL meat and bones
Includes raw and cooked meat, poultry, fish, bones
notes: Edmonton's composting facility handles meat and bones
commonMistakes: Don't put meat in the garbage

materials.name: Dairy products
notes: Recycle the container separately
commonMistakes: Don't put dairy in the garbage

materials.name: Bread and grains
notes: All grain products accepted
commonMistakes: Remove plastic packaging first

materials.name: Coffee grounds and tea bags
instructions: Place coffee grounds, paper filters, and tea bags in green cart
notes: Paper coffee filters accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic-mesh tea bags in green cart

materials.name: Eggs and eggshells
notes: Eggshells add calcium to compost
commonMistakes: Crush for faster breakdown

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Branches must be under 30cm long and 7.5cm diameter
Seasonal yard waste events for large volumes
notes: Green cart accepts food waste and yard waste together
Edmonton also hosts seasonal yard waste drop-off events
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic bags
Don't include branches over size limit

materials.name: Food-soiled paper
instructions: Edmonton accepts food-soiled paper in composting
notes: Includes paper towels, napkins, paper plates
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bag — contaminates recycling

materials.name: Pizza box (greasy)
instructions: Greasy pizza boxes go in the green cart
Tear off clean portions for the blue bag
notes: Food-soiled cardboard accepted in Edmonton composting
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy pizza boxes in the blue bag

materials.name: Compostable bags
instructions: Use certified compostable bags to line your kitchen pail
Place filled bag in green cart
notes: Look for BPI or CMA certification
commonMistakes: Don't use regular plastic bags
Don't use bags labeled 'biodegradable' — must be certified

materials.name: Styrofoam / polystyrene
instructions: Not accepted in Edmonton recycling or composting
notes: Edmonton Eco Stations accept clean styrofoam for recycling — take large amounts there
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bag
Clean styrofoam can go to an Eco Station

materials.name: Plastic bags
instructions: Some grocery stores have plastic bag drop-off bins
notes: Plastic bags jam recycling sorting equipment
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bag
Don't bag recyclables in plastic bags

materials.name: Candy and snack wrappers
notes: Multi-layer film cannot be separated
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bag

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Lined paper cups: black garbage cart
notes: Wax/plastic lining prevents cup recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put lined cups in the blue bag

materials.name: Diapers
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green cart

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag and place in black garbage cart
notes: Not accepted in Edmonton green cart
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green cart

materials.name: Receipts
notes: Thermal paper contains BPA — cannot be recycled
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bag

materials.name: Ceramics and pottery
notes: Ceramics contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bag

materials.name: Mirrors and window glass
notes: Different from container glass
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bag

materials.name: Wax paper and parchment
notes: Wax/silicone coating prevents recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bag

materials.name: Plastic straws and utensils
notes: Too small for sorting machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bag

materials.name: Hangers
instructions: Or donate to a dry cleaner
notes: Wire hangers tangle sorting machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bag

materials.name: LED and incandescent bulbs
instructions: Wrap and place in black garbage cart
notes: CFL and fluorescent bulbs go to Eco Stations
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with CFL bulbs which are hazardous

materials.name: Toothbrush
notes: Mixed materials; not recyclable curbside
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bag

materials.name: Wrapping paper
notes: Scrunch test: if it stays scrunched, may be recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put metallic wrapping paper in the blue bag

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Take to an Edmonton Eco Station
Or take to a participating retailer
Use WasteWise App to find nearest location
notes: Edmonton has 5 Eco Stations that accept electronics year-round
Electronics banned from Edmonton landfill
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in any curbside cart
Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Take to an Edmonton Eco Station
Or take to a participating retailer (Canadian Tire, Home Depot)
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries
notes: Batteries cause fires in garbage trucks
Edmonton Eco Stations accept all battery types
commonMistakes: Don't put in any curbside cart
Tape terminals to prevent fire

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to an Edmonton Eco Station
Or take to a paint retailer that accepts returns
notes: Alberta paint recycling program through product stewardship
commonMistakes: Don't pour down the drain
Don't put liquid paint in garbage

materials.name: Motor oil and automotive fluids
instructions: Take to an Edmonton Eco Station
Canadian Tire and auto parts stores also accept used oil
notes: Alberta ARMA program manages used oil recycling
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Pharmacies accept expired or unwanted medications
notes: Alberta ENVIRx program — pharmacies accept medications for free
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications
Don't put in garbage

materials.name: CFL and fluorescent bulbs
instructions: Take to an Edmonton Eco Station
Or take to participating retailers (Home Depot, IKEA)
notes: Product stewardship program covers fluorescent lighting in Alberta
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage
Don't break them

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Take to an Edmonton Eco Station
Never put in any curbside cart
notes: Pressurized containers are explosion risks
commonMistakes: Never puncture
Never put in garbage

materials.name: Household chemicals
instructions: Take to an Edmonton Eco Station
notes: Eco Stations accept a wide range of hazardous household chemicals
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains
Don't put in any curbside cart

materials.name: Needles and sharps
instructions: Take to an Edmonton pharmacy or Eco Station
notes: Never place loose sharps in any cart
commonMistakes: Never put loose sharps in any cart

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to Value Village, Goodwill, or Salvation Army
Textile recycling bins located throughout Edmonton
Edmonton Community Recycling Depots accept textiles
notes: Edmonton has Community Recycling Depots for hard-to-recycle items including textiles
commonMistakes: Don't put in any curbside cart

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Or take to an Edmonton Eco Station
notes: Alberta Recycling tire program
commonMistakes: Don't put in any curbside cart

materials.name: Appliances
instructions: Take to an Edmonton Eco Station
Or schedule large item pickup through 311
notes: Eco Stations accept large appliances
commonMistakes: Don't put in any curbside cart

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Take to an Edmonton Eco Station or landfill
notes: Some Eco Stations accept mattresses
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Cooking oil and grease
instructions: Take to an Edmonton Eco Station
Small amounts can be absorbed with paper towels and put in garbage
notes: Never pour oil down the drain
commonMistakes: Don't pour down sink or storm drains

materials.name: Smartphone / cell phone
instructions: Factory reset and wipe personal data
Take to an Edmonton Eco Station or electronics retailer
Use WasteWise App to find nearest drop-off
notes: Phones contain valuable recoverable materials
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe personal data
Don't put in garbage — battery fire risk

materials.name: Large / bulk items
instructions: Take to an Edmonton Eco Station or landfill
Or schedule a large item pickup through 311
notes: Edmonton offers large item pickup
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

recycle: Paper: newspaper, magazines, flyers, office paper, envelopes
Books and shredded paper (in paper bag)
compost: ALL food waste — fruit, vegetables, meat, bones, dairy, bread, grains
Coffee grounds, paper filters, tea bags
Yard waste — grass, leaves, small branches
trash: Styrofoam / polystyrene (or take to Eco Station)

tips: Edmonton uses blue bags for recycling, green cart for compost, and black cart for garbage
As of January 2025, EPR (Extended Producer Responsibility) program is active — mixed bagged recycling accepted at depots
Use the WasteWise App to look up how to dispose of any specific item
Edmonton has 5 Eco Stations for hazardous waste, electronics, and hard-to-recycle items
Community Recycling Depots accept textiles, small electronics, and other special items
Beverage containers can go to a bottle depot for refund under Alberta's deposit system
Green cart collects weekly — accepts all food waste including meat, bones, and dairy
Clean styrofoam can be taken to Eco Stations for recycling (not curbside)
Call 311 or visit edmonton.ca/waste for disposal questions
Download the WasteWise App for collection schedules, reminders, and item lookup

locations.name: Edmonton Eco Station — Ambleside
locations.notes: Free for Edmonton residents. One of 5 Eco Stations across the city.

locations.name: Edmonton Eco Station — Strathcona
locations.notes: Free for Edmonton residents. Central location.

locations.name: Bottle Depot (various locations)
locations.notes: Refund available on eligible beverage containers. Multiple locations across Edmonton.
